text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with pan roasted five-spice pork
loin that's right they used to say pork
was the other white meat which really is
accurate especially the loin which I've
always considered sort of the boneless
skinless chicken breast of the pork
world and that's exactly why I'm so
excited to show you this technique
because by using a fairly simple
butchery trick as well as a super-easy
asian-inspired marinade we're going to
produce something significantly more
exciting than your typical pork loin
roast so with that in mind let's go
ahead get started with the star of the
show our pork loin and what you see here
is about a two pound piece which usually
comes pretty much fully trimmed but
sometimes like this one they have a
little bit of that membrane left on top
so all we need to do is take a thin
sharp knife and slide that in between
the silver skin and the medes and as you
can see that allows us to remove that
without losing much if any meat ensure
this step is technically optional
depending on how you serve this pork
that little bit of silver skin might not
cause a problem so you decide you are
the Richard Simmons of your trim ins but
generally as a rule I do like to remove
it so we'll go ahead and clean that up
and then what we're going to do is turn
this on its side and take a larger but
still sharp knife and simply split that
as even as we can lengthwise and instead
of having one very thick piece of pork
we're going to basically end up with two
nice thick pork steaks but wait there's
more as soon as we have our loin split
in two pieces we're going to take our
knife and make some shallow slashes in
the flesh about an eighth of an inch
deep about an inch apart go in one
direction and then we'll turn and go the
other for your classic diamond pattern
and of course we'll do that to both
pieces both sides and what we just
accomplished here besides turning one
large piece of meat into two smaller
easier to cook pieces of meat
we've also by scouring it like this have
created tons of surface area which is
really going to help our marinade get
into this meat quicker and more
effectively
plus not to mention it's also going to
look really cool when it cooks but
anyway we'll go ahead and prep our pork
as shown at which point we can put
together our very simple five-spice
marinade so into a mixing bowl let's go
ahead and add some seasoned rice vinegar
as well as some finely minced garlic
we're also going to have to add some
Asian fish sauce which by the way may be
the second most important ingredient
here
we also want to add a splash of soy
sauce as well as a nice generous
application of hot sauce I'm using
sriracha and then we will season this up
with some salt as well as its good
friend and wingman freshly ground black
pepper and then last but certainly not
least a spoon of Chinese five-spice
powder which by the way may or may not
include five spices so usually has
things like ground cloves and ginger and
anise seed and fennel and stuff like
that but that can vary depending on
brand but as always I'll tell you
exactly what I used on the blog post and
then to finish this off all we need to
do is take a whisk and give it a
thorough mixing and believe it or not
that's it I told you what simple and
then what we're going to do next is
place our split and scored pork in the
bottom of some kind of dish and we will
pour in our freshly mixed marinade and
take a fork and turn those pieces over
several times until they're very nicely
coated and at this point we have some
options as far as marination goes what
I'm going to do is just leave mine right
on the counter out at room temperature
for 30 minutes tossing occasionally and
because of the way we split and scored
that meat that's going to be all we need
so this is my preferred method but you
can also throw this in a zip-top bag and
toss it in the fridge for a few hours
for the same effect and I'll talk more
about the marination time on food wishes
but like I said I just leave mine on the
counter for about a half hour at which
point it's ready to cook and as the name
would indicate we're going to go ahead
and pan roast this so what I have here
is a heavy-duty cast-iron skillet set
over medium-high heat into which I put a
little bit of vegetable oil and all
we're going to do is cook this for
approximately four to five minutes per
side or until the internal temp it's
about 145 so thanks to that butchery
trick I keep bragging about the cooking
time here is going to be relatively
quick or I start to finish this only
took me 10 minutes so I gave my first
side about four or five minutes and I
flipped it over and gave the other side
about the same and while I do hope you
use the thermometer to check your work
we can sort of use the same poke test we
use for chicken breasts or if it feels
mushy it's rare but when it kind of
firms up and springs back that generally
means you're just about perfect and the
besides cooking it on both sides until
it's done to your liking when I feel
mine is just about there I do like to
brush both sides with the marinade in
case you're wondering because I know
this does confuse a lot of people it's
always okay to use a marinade to touched
raw meat as long as it's cooked so
because we're brushing it on this hot
meat in the pan and we're flipping it
around a few times there's no danger of
any foodborne illness on the other hand
if you don't cook the marinade through
and just kind of spoon it over the
finish meat you may have some problems
and by problems I mean lawsuits so if
you are going to glaze with the marinade
make sure it gets heated through okay
but anyway to recap we're going to cook
that meat to our liking quite possibly
glazing with the marinade near the end
and once we feel and or test that our
meat is perfect we'll remove that to a
plate to rest and I didn't show it but
of course you can splash some water into
that pan and garnish that pork with some
of those pan drippings as we so often do
but anyway like I said we'll let that
meat rest I'd say at least five minutes
so you don't lose all those juices when
you slice it and then after that brief
but important respite we will go ahead
and slice that up and thanks to the way
this was trimmed and scored as well as
that very basic but magical marinade you
should be looking at some very juicy
incredibly flavorful meat but of course
I'm not going to just trust my eyes they
have lied to me many times before so I
intentionally screwed up a slice so I
could taste it and this really is
amazing just very moist and tender with
those beautiful sweet aromatics from the
Chinese five-spice in the background in
fact you can tell when I sneak a second
taste during the slicing segment it's
really good
and speaking of slicing you may be
thinking to yourself hey you're cutting
that kind of thin when you make it some
kind of mind-blowing sandwich well yes
yes I am and I'm sure we knew this
picture for two reasons first of all a
roasted pork bond me maybe the greatest
sandwich ever invented in the history of
the world and secondly that is going to
be the next video so stay tuned for that
but in the meantime so we can finish
this off with the official final taste I
slice seven or eight thicker more
perfectly cut pieces and lay that over
some steamed rice next to a little bit
of spicy jalapeno slaw as well as a
little bit of the aforementioned pan
drippings and even presented as simply
as this still tremendously delicious
like I said so flavorful and as you can
hopefully see just incredibly moist and
tender and considering how simple this
was to put together
I thought the results were stellar in
fact the only thing I wasn't thrilled
with here was my stupid fake plastic
reed placemat which is why the plate was
moving all over while I tried to eat
this let that be a lesson to you
kids never try to imitate nature the
universe hates that so while it will be
thrown away this ridiculously
ineffective placemats this pan-roasted
five-spice pork loin recipe is
definitely a keeper so like I said stay
tuned for the upcoming Bonnie episode
and in the meantime I really do hope you
give this a try soon so head over to
food wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info our usual and as
always enjoy
